World-Honored One!

Newly practicing bodhisattvas, having gone forth, not yet attained the power of wisdom but wishing to attain it, should abandon what dharmas and cultivate what dharmas, so that the power of wisdom not yet arisen can be brought forth, and the power of wisdom already arisen can be increased?
The Buddha told Maitreya Bodhisattva:
Maitreya!
Newly practicing bodhisattvas, having gone forth, wishing to increase the power of wisdom, should know the faults of material gain and should abandon them.
If they like commotion, worldly talk, indulging in sleep, extensively engaging in various tasks, and enjoy various kinds of disputation, they should all abandon such faults.
Therefore, one should abandon material gain and cultivate few desires, abandon all busyness and enjoy tranquility, and abandon all entanglements and contemplate the true meaning.
In the first and last watches of the night, one should avoid sleep and contemplate and practice accordingly.
Abandon all tasks and idle chatter, and cultivate the supramundane path with compassion for sentient beings.
Maitreya!
When novice bodhisattvas have left the household life but have not yet attained the power of wisdom and wish to attain it, they should abandon those dharmas and cultivate those dharmas.
Why is it so?

Maitreya!ğŸ”½For those bodhisattvas who have left the household life but have not yet attained the power of wisdom and wish to attain it, if they do not abandon material gain and do not cultivate few desires, it is impossible for them to give rise to the power of wisdom that has not yet arisen and to cause the power of wisdom that has already arisen to increase.

If they do not abandon busyness and do not abide in tranquility, it is also impossible for them to give rise to the power of wisdom that has not yet arisen and to cause the power of wisdom that has already arisen to increase.

Not abandoning worldly affairs, not contemplating the true meaning, not giving rise to the power of wisdom that should be given rise to, and not being able to increase the power of wisdom that has already arisen - this is impossible.

Engrossed in sleep during the first and last watches of the night, never being mindful, not abandoning worldly affairs while contemplating, delighting in frivolous discourse, being unable to cultivate the supramundane path, not giving rise to loving-kindness towards sentient beings, not giving rise to the power of wisdom that should be given rise to, and not being able to increase the power of wisdom that has already arisen - this is also impossible.
Maitreya!

Therefore, if bodhisattvas have not yet attained the power of wisdom but wish to attain it, they should abandon all dharmas that should be abandoned and cultivate all dharmas that should be cultivated.
Why is this?
The wisdom of bodhisattvas arises from causes and conditions. If there are no causes and conditions, it will never arise. Only when causes and conditions come together can it arise.

At that time, the World-Honored One spoke a verse, saying:
In this life, always suffering and distressed, leaving forbearance and much anger,
Enemies give rise to harmful thoughts, this is called the fault of frivolous discourse.
Demons and their retinue all give rise to joyful thoughts,
Losing all wholesome dharmas, this is called the fault of frivolous discourse.
Wholesome dharmas not yet arisen do not arise, always dwelling in disputes,
Creating karma for the evil destinies, this is called the fault of frivolous discourse.
The body has much ugliness, born into an inferior family,
Speaking always stammering and harsh, this is called the fault of frivolous discourse.
Hearing the Dharma, unable to uphold it, or hearing without listening,
Always separated from all good friends, this is called the fault of frivolous discourse.
Encountering evil friends, difficult to escape from the path,
Always hearing disagreeable words, this is called the fault of frivolous discourse.
Wherever they are born, they always harbor doubts in their minds,
And are unable to understand the Dharma, this is called the fault of frivolous discourse.
They are always born in the eight difficult situations, far from the place without difficulty,
And are replete with no benefit, this is called the fault of frivolous discourse.
They create many obstacles for the good, and regress from right thought,
And what they receive is often resented, this is called the fault of frivolous discourse.
All these faults arise from frivolous discourse,
Therefore, the wise should quickly distance themselves from it.
Those who engage in frivolous discourse find it difficult to realize great enlightenment,
Therefore, the wise should also not associate with them.
In places of frivolous and contentious discourse, many afflictions arise,
The wise should distance themselves, going a hundred yojanas.
They should also not build dwellings nearby,
Therefore, those who have left the household life should not dwell in disputes.
You have no fields, houses, wives, children, or servants,
Up to positions of honor and so forth - what reason is there to engage in disputes?
Those who have left the household life dwell in tranquility, their bodies clothed in the Dharma robes,
Respected by all the sages - they should cultivate a mind of patience.
Those who engage in such frivolous arguments increase their poisonous and harmful thoughts,
And will fall into the evil destinies - therefore, one should cultivate patience.
Imprisonment, bondage, punishment, harm, and beatings,
Such sufferings all arise from disputes.
Those who engage in such frivolous arguments always encounter bad friends,
Their reputation does not increase, and they never have a joyful mind.
If one abandons disputes, no one will be able to find an opportunity [to harm them],
Their relatives will not be estranged, and they will encounter good friends.
In the vehicle one attains purity, karmic hindrances are exhausted without remainder,

Disputes have many faults, non-disputes possess merits,
If there are practitioners, they should abide in patience.
